dpo.title: Data Protection Officer
dpo.paragraph: Articles 37 to 39 of GDPR define the cases in which a Data Protection Officer must be appointed and his/her relevant tasks. The appointment of a Data Protection Officer, while not mandatory, is strongly recommended. As data controller and HireSweet as processor, we shall publish the contacts of our respective Data Protection Officers in order to be communicated to the supervisory authorities.

step2.content: Use HireSweet to its full power and save time by syncing your email threads with the candidates
step2.details: By authorizing HireSweet, you will give access to your email data. This data will be secured and HireSweet will ensure the confidentiality of any personal information

step0.content:
You picked us to help you with recruiting: congratulations!

Here's a quick walkthrough of everything you need to be up and running today.

step1.header: “Discover”: A direct access to all candidates

content.part1: Every Monday our talent pool is refreshed for everyone to access. You can sift through the candidates and save your
content.part3: Pro trick: Never miss a new batch by creating a recurring event in your Google Calendar.

step2.header: Jobs: your daily selection of candidates

content.part1: You can also create jobs for the HireSweet team to upload the most relevant candidates as soon as they register.
content.part2: This is requested to run complex workflows: Autopilot, ATS Integration, etc.

step3.header: The ball is in your court!

content.part1: You just need to connect your email account to be able to engage with the candidates.
content.part2: If you need help on anything, please reach out to your Account Strategist who will be delighted to help.

step0.content:
We built our new design with our users in mind. We changed fonts, optimized line spacing, changed colors, released new features - all the information you are looking for is now available much more easily and your productivity will improve overnight.

Let us walk you through it!

step1.content:
Because large organization have felt overwhelmed, we now allow users to see only the jobs they own.

We also allow you to create departments to better organize your jobs in different teams.

step2.header: Import resumes and create customizable evaluation forms
step2.content:
Many people have been asking for that feature: you can now import PDFs (Resumes, Cover Letter) to candidates’ profiles.

If you don’t have an ATS yet, you can now manage your entire interview process with our brand new customizable evaluation forms - keep all your data and your team in one place!

step3.header: Perform HireSweet actions from LinkedIn and Gmail
step3.content:
We released a new improved Chrome extension for LinkedIn, Gmail and Google Calendar. Most HireSweet actions can be performed directly from the extension: leave a note, change the pipeline step, etc.

That’s it for today folks, enjoy our new design and feel free to leave your comments for the team in the chat!

0.title: Tech recruitment: statistical analysis of high performing messages
0.subtitle: Published on March 22, 2019
0.extract: HireSweet is an Artificial Intelligence tool that automates the sourcing of mainly tech profiles. Every day, several thousand messages are sent from our platform.
0.author: HireSweet

1.title: Tech Hiring: Double your response rate
1.subtitle: Published on March 21, 2019
1.extract: The first message you send to a potential candidate is crucial. If it is sent to the right person (has the right skills) at the right time (is open to the market) and contains clear information; you maximize your chances of getting an answer.
1.author: HireSweet

2.title: 5 ways to source and hire tech profiles
2.subtitle: Published on March 11, 2019
2.extract: Recruitment is a key function, but it is not an easy game. Especially for start-ups who have the opportunity to carefully select the people they hire.
2.author: HireSweet

3.title: 4-hour preparation before hiring
3.subtitle: Published on April 10, 2019
3.extract: When you are looking to recruit a developer or other tech profiles it is often difficult to identify the objective criteria that would make a profile the perfect candidate.
3.author: HireSweet

4.title: Do like the best Engineering blogs!
4.subtitle: Published on June 17, 2019
4.extract: More and more employer-brand strategies are flourishing. The intention is to enable companies to address their potential future employees through different channels (media, events, trade fairs, online presence, etc.).
4.author: HireSweet

5.title: How to embed reference checks into your tech interviewing process
5.subtitle: Published on July 15, 2019
5.extract: Reference checks are paramount. Past work success is one of the best predictors of future work performance. It might even filter better than your technical assessment. You should put more emphasis on reference checks.
5.author: Robin Choy

6.title: First time hiring Tech talent? Here are the books you must absolutely read
6.subtitle: Published on July 25, 2019
6.extract: Hiring is not tough, it just requires dedication, care and humility. People often struggle when they want to hire tech talent, and they are most open when they have already hired before.
6.author: Robin Choy

7.title: We asked Silicon Valley Engineering Leaders “What’s your favorite Engineer book?
7.subtitle: Published on August 14, 2019
7.extract: On Wednesday we attended & sponsored Plato's awesome Engineering event Elevate in San Francisco (600 attendees, 30 speakers, 100 workshops)
7.author: Robin Choy

8.title: Five questions you should ask during your screening calls
8.subtitle: Published on September 24, 2019
8.extract: Screening via a phone call time is most effective. During these 15 to 30 minutes, you’ll have to assess whether you’ll launch a proper interview process with the candidate.
8.author: Robin Choy

hiresweetTip.title: HireSweet Tips
hiresweetTip.content:
• Introduce yourself: Tell them more about yourself, your company, and your product!

• Show traction: Describe what you have accomplished so far, give them as many KPIs as you can.

• Show them: Save your prospective candidates some time by sharing some relevant links (that you are proud of) with them.

• Reassure them about funding & package: Give precise details - it will save you time down the road.

pipeline.passthroughRatesParagraph: Passthrough rates will show you, as a ratio, the number of contacts who moved from one stage to the next.

ever.paragraph: You have selected "Over the period": the number of contacts who have been in any given stage since the project's creation. Those numbers are added together: in "Replied" will be counted all the contacts currently in "Replied", "Interested", "Hired" and all those having been archived from one of those categories. A contact in several projects will be counted several times.
ever.alternativeTitle: Want to see a snapshot of your evolution?
ever.alternativeParagraph: If you select "Right now" in the top right, you will see a snapshot of your evolution.

current.paragraph: You have selected "Right now": a snapshot of how many contacts are currently in each stage. A contact in several projects is counted several times.
current.alternativeTitle: Want to see your evolution over the period?
current.alternativeParagraph: If you select "Over the period" in the top right, you will see your evolution over the period.

pipeline.manualMoveParagraph: Contacts need to be moved to "Interested" manually. If they haven't been, that could explain why your passthrough rate "Contacted" > "Replied" could be lower than the average reply rate you see in your sequences.
pipeline.deletedParagraph: Contacts removed from a project or deleted from your contact database will not be counted (that's why we recommend archiving your contacts and not deleting them).

pending.title: Number of contacts that you’ve added to a project but have not been contacted yet
pending.multiMissionParagraph: A contact in several projects will be counted several times.

in-progress.title: Number of contacts that you have contacted or started a sequence in a project
in-progress.multiMoveParagraph: A contact can only be counted once per project - if the same contact is moved several times to "Contacted", they will still count as one.
in-progress.revertMoveParagraph: Similarly, if the contact is moved to "Replied" and then back to "Contacted" within the same project, they will still be counted as "Contacted" only once.
in-progress.multiMissionParagraph: However, a contact in several projects will be counted several times.

replied.title: Number of contacts that have been moved to the "Replied" step of a project or that have replied to your email from a sequence
replied.multiMoveParagraph: A contact can only be counted once per project - if the same contact is moved several times to "Replied", they will still count as one.
replied.revertMoveParagraph: Similarly, if the contact is moved to "Interested" and then back to "Replied" within the same project, they will still be counted as "Replied" only once.
replied.skipParagraph: Finally, if a contact is archived and the reason was "Contact not interested" or "Contact interested", they will be counted as "Replied" even though they might not have been manually moved to "Replied".
replied.multiMissionParagraph: However, a contact in several projects will be counted several times.

interested.title: Number of contacts that have been moved to the "Interested" step of a project
interested.multiMoveParagraph: A contact can only be counted once per project - if the same contact is moved several times to "Interested", they will still count as one.
interested.revertMoveParagraph: Similarly, if the contact is moved to "Hired" and then back to "Interested" within the same project, they will still be counted as "Interested" only once.
interested.skipParagraph: Finally, if a contact is archived and the reason was "Contact interested", they will be counted as "Interested" even though they were not moved to "Interested" manually.
interested.multiMissionParagraph: However, a contact in several projects will be counted several times.

hired.title: Number of contacts that have been moved to the "Hired" step of a project
hired.multiMoveParagraph: A contact can only be counted once per project - if the same contact is moved several times to "Hired", they will still count as one.
hired.multiMissionParagraph: However, a contact in several projects will be counted several times.

archived.title: Number of contacts that have been moved to the "Archived" step of a project
archived.definitionParagraph: This number is the sum of all the archived contacts, whatever the archive reason you may have selected when archiving them.
archived.multiMoveParagraph: A contact can only be counted once per project - if the same contact is moved several times to "Archived", they will still count as one.
archived.multiMissionParagraph: However, a contact in several projects will be counted several times.

common.hiresweetCount: Only contacts currently in HireSweet CRM are counted. If you delete a contact, it will not be counted in this chart.
common.barDetails: You can see a list of the contacts counted in this graph by clicking on the bars.
common.numberDetails: You can see a list of the contacts counted in this graph by clicking on the numbers.

pipeline.title: Evolution of contacts across the different pipeline stages

in-progress.title: Number of contacts that have been moved to the "Contacted" step, split by users of your team
in-progress.usefulnessParagraph: It's one of the best indicators you can track in order to visualise how many contacts will be moved to "Interested".
in-progress.multiMoveParagraph: If a contact is moved several times to "Contacted", the contact will be counted several times for this graph.

interested.title: Number of contacts that have been moved to the "Interested" step, split by users of your team
interested.recommendationParagraph: Our recommendation is to move a contact to the "Interested" stage when they agree to an initial conversation (or phone call).
interested.usefulnessParagraph: It's one of the best indicators you can track in order to visualise how many contacts will be moved to "Hired".
interested.multiMoveParagraph: If a contact is moved several times to "Interested", the contact will be counted several times for this graph.

hired.title: Number of contacts that have been moved to the "Hired" step, split by users of your team
hired.surprisedParagraph: Once a contact is moved to "Hired" once, they will count for this graph - even though they might then be "Archived" for whatever reason (they finally decided to not join the company for example).
hired.multiMoveParagraph: If a contact is moved several times to "Hired", the contact will be counted several times for this graph.

archived.title: Number of contacts that have been archived, split by users of your team
archived.multiMoveParagraph: If a contact is moved several times to "Archived", the contact will be counted several times for this graph.

sourced.title: Number of contacts that have been added to a project, split by period
sourced.multiMissionParagraph: If a contact has been added to multiple projects, the contact will be counted multiple times in this graph.

common.countedTasksParagraph: These tasks will be counted completed whether done through a sequence or individually:

uncountedTasks.paragraph: These tasks do not count as completed:
uncountedTasks.loggedReply: Logged reply from a contact (manually or automatically)
uncountedTasks.loggedActivityOutside: Recruiter activity logged outside of a task
uncountedTasks.loggedLinkedInOutside: LinkedIn message or invitation logged automatically outside of a task

common.timeParagraph: Tasks are counted when they are completed (not when they are created).

typeByUser.title: Number of tasks completed by the users of your team over the period

completedByUser.title: Number of tasks completed by the users of your team split by period

completedByType.title: Number of tasks completed split by type of tasks and split by period

prefixDisplayMode.title: Display mode
prefixDisplayMode.explanationParagraph: It seems like this sequence has been modified during its lifetime. In order to take those changes into account in a way that makes sense, two display modes are available.
prefixDisplayMode.pathParagraph: Contacts are separated by which version of the sequence they went through. A summary of all the steps from the moment they were enrolled to the moment they were contacted or gave an answer is presented.
prefixDisplayMode.stepParagraph: This mode merges all versions of the sequence and focuses on the number of steps that happened before a contact was contacted or gave an answer.

kpis.title: Performance and conversion rate of your sequences
kpis.timeSpanParagraph: We only count contacts that were enrolled in the sequence during the time period selected in the top right (ex: "Last 180 days").
kpis.categoriesParagraph: For more explanations about each category please refer to the explanations attached to that category when browsing the graph.

enrolled.title: Number of contacts enrolled in a sequence over the given period
enrolled.surprisedParagraph: Some contacts might have been enrolled in a sequence but have never actually been contacted (meaning the first sequence step was not completed) - hence this number being different from the one in "Contacted".

contacted.title: Number of contacts in a sequence that were contacted over the given period
contacted.explanationsParagraph: "Contacted" means at least one step in the sequence has been completed.

opened.title: Percentage of contacts in a sequence having opened at least one tracked email
opened.countParagraph: If a contact opens an email several times, the percentage doesn't increase as they still only count as one contact. The same logic applies if they open several emails in the same sequence.
opened.percentageParagraph: This percentage is the ratio between the number of emails opened and the number of contacts contacted via a tracked email.
opened.blockersParagraph: Some people block email tracking, which could negatively impact this ratio, making it lower than the response rate!
opened.settingsParagraph: Your emails might or might not be tracked depending on what you picked in your settings - This is also why the total number of emails tracked could be lower than the total number of emails.

clicked.title: Percentage of contacts who clicked at least one tracked link in a sequence
clicked.countParagraph: If a contact clicks a link several times, the percentage will not increase as they still only count as one contact. The same logic applies if they click several links in the same sequence.
clicked.percentageParagraph: This percentage is the ratio between the number of clicks and the number of contacts contacted with an email containing a tracked link.
clicked.blockersParagraph: Some people block click tracking, so this number could be inaccurate.
clicked.settingsParagraph: Your links might or might not be tracked depending on what you picked in your settings - This is also why the total number of emails tracked can be lower than the total number of emails.

replied.title: Percentage of contacts who replied to a sequence
replied.sourceParagraph: A reply is either detected automatically (for the emails and LinkedIn Inmails if synchronisation is enabled) or logged manually by the user (for LinkedIn messages for instance).
replied.stagesParagraph: Within a project, contacts moved to a stage after "Contacted" will be counted. Archived contacts will too if with the reason for archiving was "Contact interested" or "Contact not interested".
replied.percentageParagraph: This ratio is relative to the number of replies and the number of contacts contacted.

interested.title: Percentage of contacts who replied positively to a sequence
interested.sourceParagraph: A reply is either detected automatically (for the emails and LinkedIn Inmails if synchronisation is enabled) or logged manually by the user (for LinkedIn messages for instance).
interested.stagesParagraph: Within a project, a contact moved to a stage after "Interested" will be counted. Archived contacts will too if with the reason for archiving was "Contact interested".
interested.percentageParagraph: This ratio is between the number of positive replies and the number of contacts contacted.

cohorts.title: Conversion of your sequences split by period
cohorts.explanationParagraph: For every time period, you can find the current status ("Contacted", "Replied", "Replied positively") of the contacts contacted through a sequence.
cohorts.uniquenessParagraph: For a given sequence, a contact counted as "Replied positively" does not count as "Contacted" or "Replied". Only the contact's latest status within the sequence is counted.
cohorts.startParagraph: Contacts are counted once the first task of a sequence is completed (not at the enrollment date or at the reply date).
cohorts.multiSequenceParagraph: If a contact is contacted within several sequences during a given time period, the contact will be counted several times.
cohorts.usefulnessParagraph: This graph allows you to measure the impact of your sequences initiated during a given time period (day, week, month or quarter), showing you total replies and positive replies.
cohorts.exampleParagraph: You could, for instance, see that during the second quarter of the year, all sequences have generated x non-positive replies and y positive replies, for z no reply. You can then compare these numbers between quarters.
cohorts.surprisedParagraph: For each time period (day, week, month, quarter), this number is always a minimum given that contacts can keep replying and therefore improve the numbers.
cohorts.recencyParagraph: It is "expected" to see a declining graph on recent periods as contacts need time to reply. Our recommendation is to look at numbers for periods having ended more than 3 weeks ago (as most of the sequences are shorter than 3 weeks).

campaignFunnels.title: Performance and conversion rate of your campaigns
campaignFunnels.timeSpanParagraph: We only count contacts that were enrolled in the campaign during the time period selected in the top right (ex: "Last 180 days")..
campaignFunnels.detailsParagraph: For more explanations about each category please refer to the explanations attached to that category when browsing the graph.

nbEnrolled.title: Number of contacts enrolled in a campaign over the given period
nbEnrolled.contactedParagraph: Some contacts might have been enrolled in a campaign but have never actually been contacted - hence this number being different from the one in "Contacted".

nbContacted.title: Number of contacts in a campaign that were contacted over the given period
nbContacted.definitionParagraph: "Contacted" means that the email was sent to the contact.

nbOpened.title: Number of contacts in a campaign having opened at least one tracked email
nbOpened.multiOpenParagraph: If a contact opens an email several times, this number doesn't increase as they still only count as one contact. The same logic applies if they open several emails in the same campaign.
nbOpened.trackingParagraph: Your emails might or might not be tracked depending on what you picked in your settings - This is also why the total number of emails tracked could be lower than the total number of emails.

nbClicked.title: Number of contacts who clicked at least one tracked link in a campaign
nbClicked.multiClickParagraph: If a contact clicks a link several times, this number will not increase as they still only count as one contact. The same logic applies if they click several links in the same campaign.
nbClicked.blockersParagraph: Some people block click tracking, so this number could be inaccurate.
nbClicked.trackingParagraph: Your links might or might not be tracked depending on what you picked in your settings - This is also why the total number of links tracked can be lower than the total number of emails.

nbUnsubscribe.title: Number of contacts who clicked an unsubscribe link in a campaign

common.genderLabeling: How does the gender labeling work?
common.genderLabelingParagraph: HireSweet automatic gender labeling is based on public first name lists. We do not use the picture of the contact or any other information. If the first name is not in the public lists, we label the contact as unknown. You can always edit this information in the tab "Information" of a contact.

sequences.title: Sequences
sequences.text: A sequence is a list of automated or manual tasks such as sending an email, a LinkedIn message, a text message, etc. in order to get a positive reply from a contact
